data.text: Ride through rain. I carry a variety of rain and cold weather gear in a platypus (like camel back) backpack when the weather is threatening. Waterproof full finger gloves, flease vests top and bottom microfiber and polypropylene arm and leg warmers and neoprene booties are in there. I have also riden through snow and sleet in this gear but it was a close call between hypothermia and the roads icing up so get out of snow ASAP. As absolutely shattered as I was by descending a major pass in snow I at least had the presence of mind to stop in a bar with a pot belly stove when I hit civilization. Twenty minutes later I was good to go and when I got to the hotel I had no problem checking in or getting into my room. Others who arrived at the hotel moments after me were in bad shape and were unable to get their keys into the lock to get out of the cold. I helped a couple guys before I showered and more afterwards.

data.text: Mentioning lightning reminded me of a time cycling with my wife in high hills when we entered electric cloud. The strange cloud went over in about 15 minutes and we rested and both slept for about an hour. A very weird experience.
